para.literalLayout: We incubated (2006) northern Alaskan soils (boreal and tundra) at two temperatures (5 degC and 15 degC) and two levels of nitrogen addition (with and without) to directly test for nitrogen limitation of inorganic nitrogen production rate and explore the interaction between temperature and nitrogen limitation. Over the 3-month laboratory incubation, we measured initial extratable inorganic nitrogen and inorganic nitrogen production rates from organic and mineral soils from four different ecosystem types (boreal burned, boreal unburned, moist acidic, moist non-acidic). To charactarize the soils, we also measured total C, total N, microbial biomass, isotopes values (delta 13, delta14), total free amino acid, and total soluble protein.

Three replicates of each soil were sampled in each site.

FIELD: We sampled three cores of organic and mineral soil horizons from four high northern latitude ecosystems located in arctic tundra and boreal forests within Alaska, USA. Sites included recently burned and unburned black spruce forests near Delta Junction in interior Alaska, moist acidic tussock tundra and non-acidic tundra near Toolik Lake. Soil sampling was conducted on 24 July 2001 for the tundra and 5-13 July 2006 for the black spruce forests. LAB: We used an aerobic laboratory incubation to estimate inorganic nitrogen, inorganic nitrogen transformation, total soluble protein, total free amino acid, microbial biomass, isotopes, total carbon, and total nitrogen. We estimated net nitrification and net nitrogen mineralization rates for each soil by extracting with 0.5 M K2SO4. Ammonium and nitrate in soil extracts were determined colorimetrically using an Astoria-Pacific colorimetric autoanalyzer. Total soluble protein was extracted with 0.1 M NaHCO3. Soluble protein was measured against ?-globulin (0 to 500 ?g/ml) using a microplate reader. Total free amino acids were extracted with distilled water using the same weight:volume ratios as used for the total soluble protein extraction. Amino acid concentration was determined as nitrogen using leucine as the standard (0 to 200 ?M). Soil microbial biomass was determined after the 3-month incubation with the chloroform fumigation extraction method. The soil samples were fumigated for 1 d in chloroform vapor followed by extraction (K2SO4) and filtration. Extract subsamples (fumigated and non-fumigated) were digested by persulfate oxidation and analyzed for nitrate colorimetrically using an Astoria-Pacific colorimetric autoanalyzer. Total soil C and N were measured on subsamples of initial soil cores using a Costech ECS 4010 Elemental Analyzer. We performed isotope measurements for gaseous samples of delta 13 CO2 and delta14 CO2 respired after 3-month of incubation time.
